content.div:
With the Bachelor season finale just around the corner, I decided to get the inside scoop on what exactly it would be like to try out for the upcoming Canadian version of the hit show.

It was a windy Saturday morning in downtown Toronto when I entered the Intercontinental Hotel, where I was greeted by the sight of a couple hundred women who were gathered in hopes of finding love (or at least fame) on The Bachelor Canada.

Everywhere I looked, there were young, gorgeous girls hoping to woo the producers and get a spot on the sure-to-be hit show.

Toronto was one of the last stops on the Bachelor Canada tour, but it was easy to tell that the creators still hadn’t found all of their contestants.

Before my audition, I got the chance to chat with the producers to see exactly what they were looking for in potential candidates. Claire Freeland, Director of Original Programming at Rogers Media and Executive Producer of The Bachelor Canada, dismissed talk that they’re looking for contestants who are overly dramatic on camera.

"I don't think you can do that," she said. "Women come and try out for the show, not to try and be the person that we want them to be. Don't try to come in and be the crazy person, or the wallflower, or the Courtney. Just be yourself."

"We don't believe you can cast a villain,” Sean De Vries, Supervising Producer of Force Four Entertainment, added. “I think what happens is that it's much like dating in real life, where you meet a guy and you think he's fantastic, and then he turns out not to be who you think he was. That happens very often, and the bachelor has to figure this out with 25 bachelorettes."

Armed with their advice, I filled out a pile of forms, and then my group was shuffled into a few different rooms to get ID'd and have our photos taken. While the ladies were lovely, I must say that at the ripe ol' age of 26, I felt old. While I was waiting to be called in for my one-on-one interview, I overheard one girl saying that her father didn't approve of her audition so she whined to him, "Dad, I'm 19 now; I can do what I want!" While I don't expect reality shows to only feature mature ladies, I had to wonder if most of these young girls were looking for committed relationships -- or just 15 minutes of fame.

Despite feeling ancient, I moved on to the one-on-one portion of my interview. Imagine being in a bright spotlight, mic'd up with a camera in your face and then being asked to explain your dating history and tell the stories you usually only share over a bottle of wine with your girlfriends.

Most of the opening questions were softballs, (why do you want to be on the show? have you ever been in love? etc.), but when I was asked to tell a complete stranger why my love life up to this point has been a failure, it got a little depressing (I didn’t really want to divulge that my dating history includes a guy who tried to kill himself, one who stalked me and one who was the epitome of Katy Perry's "Hot and Cold"). Still, I managed to get through it, all while trying to present the most charming, wittiest version of myself (which is not the easiest thing to do when you're feeling a bit interrogated).

All in all, it was a pretty eye-opening experience and despite feeling a bit out of place at times, I'm glad I did it. Hey, a lot of people PAY to have someone listen to their problems, right?! In the wise words of infamous Bachelor contestant Courtney Robertson, “winning!”

Stay tuned to hear the outcome of my application. And for those ladies I haven’t scared off, there’s still time to try out! Online applications will be accepted until March 15, 2012.

-mirandaf@dose.ca

link.Abstract: VANCOUVER — The husband of a star in Vancouver’s version of the reality TV show Real Housewives is a star of sorts himself, acquitted along with notorious crime boss Bindy Johal in Vancouver’s most sensational gangland murder trial.

link.title: Real Housewives Vancouver Hubby Has Notorious Past
